problem.tex: Let $f$ be a holomorphic function defined on the disc $|z|<R$. For $0\leq r<R$ define \[M(r)=\sup_{|z|=r}|f(z)|\] Show that $M$ is a continuous, nondecreasing function which is strictly increasing iff $f$ is nonconstant.

solution.tex: The maximum modulus principle states that if $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ is holomorphic and $G$ is a region with $\overline G\subset\Omega$ then the maximum of $f$ on $\overline G$ occurs on $\partial G$. Moreover, if there is a point $a\in G$ with $|f(a)|=\sup_G|f(z)|$, then $f$ must be constant on $\Omega$. Let $B_r=\{z:|z|<r\}$ and $C_r=\{z:|z|=r\}$. Then for all $r$ with $0\leq r<R$, we know $\overline{B_r}\subset B_R$. By the maximum modulus principle, \[\sup_{z\in B_r}|f(z)|=\sup_{z\in C_r}|f(z)|=M(r).\] The left hand side clearly is a nondecreasing function of $r$ because $B_r$ is a larger set as $r$ gets larger. That shows that $M$ is nondecreasing. Moreover, if there are two points $r_1<r_2$ for which $M(r_1)=M(r_2)$ then there is a point $a\in \overline{B_{r_1}}\subset B_{\frac{1}{2}(r_1+r_2)}$ with $|f(a)|=\sup_{B_{r_2}}|f(z)|$. By the maximum modulus principle, $f$ must then be constant on $B_{r_2}$. The uniqueness principle then forces $f$ to be constant on $B_R$. The fact that $M$ is continuous follows from the fact that $f$ is continuous, but we will give some details there now. We already know that $M$ is an increasing function, we just need to show it does not jump. Let $0\leq s<R$ and $\delta>0$ be given. Let $\epsilon'>0$ be small enough that $s+\epsilon'<R$. Let $B=\{z:|z|<s+\epsilon'\}$. Then $|f|:\overline{B}\to[0,\infty)$ is a uniformly continuous function (uniformly because of compactness). Let $\epsilon>0$ be small enough that for any $z,w\in B$ with $|z-w|<\epsilon$, $|f(z)-f(w)|<\delta$. Also choose $\epsilon<\epsilon'$. Now we show $M$ does not jump at $s$. For any $z$ with $s<|z|<s+\epsilon$, there is a $w$ with $|w|=s$ and $|w-z|<\epsilon$. Then $|f(z)-f(w)|<\delta$, so \[|f(z)|-|f(w)|\leq|f(z)-f(w)|<\delta\] \[|f(z)|<|f(w)|+\delta\leq M(s)+\delta\] because $w\in C_s$. This last inequality shoes that for all $s'$ with $s<s'<s+\epsilon$, \[M(s')< M(s)+\delta.\] Thus $M$ does not jump past $\delta$ at $s$. This is for all $\delta>0$, so $M$ does not jump at $s$. This is for all $s$, so $M$ never jumps. Thus $M$ is continuous.
